message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of multiple bruises, retinal hemorrhages, and a subdural hemorrhage in a young child with a history of a fall is highly concerning for non-accidental trauma, also known as child abuse. Informing child protective services is the most important follow-up plan to ensure the safety and well-being of the child. Providing parents with anticipatory guidance or reassurance that accidents are common would not be appropriate in this situation. Referral to genetics for further testing is also not relevant to this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of purplish bruises and retinal hemorrhages in the absence of any other trauma suggests non-accidental trauma, commonly known as shaken baby syndrome. Informing child protective services is the most important step in ensuring the safety of the child. The other options may also be appropriate, but informing child protective services is the priority.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest non-accidental trauma or child abuse. The most important follow-up plan is to inform child protective services to ensure the safety of the child. Providing parents with anticipatory guidance or reassurance is not appropriate in this situation, and referral to genetics is not indicated based on the information given.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical findings suggest non-accidental trauma or shaken baby syndrome. It is important to inform child protective services to ensure the safety of the child and provide appropriate support to the family. Option B and C are not appropriate in this situation. Option D may be considered, but it is not the most important follow-up plan at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical findings are concerning for physical abuse, and it is important to inform child protective services and investigate further to ensure the safety of the child. Providing anticipatory guidance or reassurance are not appropriate in this case, and referral to genetics is not indicated unless there is suspicion of a genetic disorder contributing to the symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of purplish bruises, retinal hemorrhages, and a subdural hemorrhage are strongly suggestive of non-accidental trauma (NAT) or child abuse. Therefore, it is crucial to inform child protective services and ensure the safety of the child. Providing parents with anticipatory guidance, reassurance, and referral to genetics are not appropriate actions in the context of suspected child abuse.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Given the findings of purplish bruises, retinal hemorrhages, and a subdural hemorrhage after a fall, this patient is at high risk for child abuse. The most important follow-up plan is to inform child protective services to ensure the safety of the child. The other options may be appropriate in certain situations but are not the most important follow-up plan in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the subdural hemorrhage and retinal hemorrhages, are highly suspicious for non-accidental trauma or shaken baby syndrome. Therefore, informing child protective services is the most important follow-up plan to ensure the safety and well-being of the child. Anticipatory guidance and reassurance that accidents are common may not address the underlying issue, and referral to genetics for further testing is not relevant in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of multiple bruises and retinal hemorrhages, and a subdural hemorrhage suggest non-accidental trauma or child abuse. Therefore, it is mandatory to inform child protective services to prevent further harm to the child. Providing anticipatory guidance, reassuring that accidents are common, and referral to genetics for further testing are not appropriate management plans in this scenario.

The purplish bruises and retinal hemorrhages are suggestive of non-accidental trauma or child abuse, and so child protective services should be informed to ensure the safety and well-being of the child. Providing parents with anticipatory guidance or reassurance that accidents are common is not appropriate in cases of suspected child abuse. Referral to genetics for further testing is not necessary based on the presentation described.
